journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering

title-group.article-title: Application of different strategies of partitioned fluid–structure interaction simulation for a single-blade pump impeller

article-meta.aff: 1Research Center of Fluid Machinery Engineering and Technology, Jiangsu University, China
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Duisburg-Essen, Germany

author-notes.corresp: Friedrich-Karl Benra, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Turbomachinery, Faculty of Engineering Sciences, University of Duisburg-Essen, Lotharstraße 1, 47048 Duisburg, Germany. Email: friedrich.benra@uni-due.de

abstract.p: In this article, the one-way and two-way coupling strategies are used, respectively, for partitioned fluid–structure interaction simulation to numerically investigate the hydrodynamic force and vibration of single-blade pump impeller at design and off-design conditions, and the effect of mesh resolution on the two-way coupling results is also considered. The comparison analysis of the calculated results with different strategies, involving aspects of amplitude and phase, has been carried out. In addition, the simulated impeller deflection results are also compared with experimental results by proximity sensors. The analysis of the results show that for different mesh resolutions, the amplitude of deflection with fine mesh is bigger than that with coarse mesh for almost all the operational conditions, and the phase differences can be clearly found for part-load conditions. The amplitude of hydrodynamic force calculated with coarse mesh is smaller than that is calculated with fine mesh in almost all quadrants for each flow rate, except the first quadrant for Q = 11 L/s. Furthermore, the amplitude of deflection calculated by two-way coupling strategy is bigger than that is calculated by one-way coupling strategy in certain quadrants for each flow rate, and the phase results have a good agreement for different coupling strategies. The amplitude of hydrodynamic force calculated by one-way coupling is just slightly smaller, and the phase difference can only be observed for Q = 42 L/s and Q = 11 L/s conditions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Single-blade pumps play an important role in the field for transporting water containing large amounts of solids and fibers, therefore called no-clogging sewage water pump. Because of the special type of blade structure, without considering the mechanical unbalance, strong asymmetrical unsteady flow is caused under design and off-design conditions, and periodically hydrodynamic force acting on the impeller surface also exists, which can lead to strong impeller vibrations.1 The numerical structure analysis for vibrations earlier was carried out with FEM theory only, and the extremely complicated pump internal flow was considered using CFD tools. However, the structure vibration caused by flow excitation force was not easily analyzed, because for the solid part the natural view is the material (Lagrangian) description, and for the fluid it is the spatial (Eulerian) description. This presents a big challenge for the numerical simulation to predict the flow-induced impeller vibration behavior in a pump, especially for the time-dependent problems.

The fluid–structure interaction (FSI) is a natural effect which is recognized by people from aero-elastic problem in early 19th century. And the FSI phenomenon, which can lead to increased potential for flow-induced vibrations, exists between complex inner flow and structures, not only in pump, but also in other fluid machineries. With the development of FSI theory and solution method, the application of FSI simulation is becoming more and more popular for flow-induced structure vibration research. Zhang et al.2,3 conducted the FEM and LES simulation in a Francis hydroturbine blade passage in order to study the dynamic FSI. Benra et al.4–6 investigated the flow-induced vibrations of a commercial single-blade sewage water pump in detail using numerical and experimental methods. Determination of the rotor oscillations is possible by using numerical codes for the transient flow in the pump and for structure dynamics of the rotor. Kato et al.7 predicted the noise from a multi-stage centrifugal pump using one-way coupling method. Langthjem et al.8 investigated flow-induced noise in a two-dimensional centrifugal pump considering FSI. He believed that the interaction between fluid and rotating impeller blades plays an important role in generating noise. Münch et al.9 presented an alternative method which linearizes the hydrodynamic load of a rigid, oscillating hydrofoil, and the excellent agreement is found between analytical and FSI results. Campbell et al.10 developed and validated a method for the performance computation of an expandable impeller pump, and the simulations of the test problem show good agreement with the experimental results and demonstrate the need for several sub-iterations of the solver even for the quasi-steady simulations.

Two different approaches can be used depending on the physical nature of the interaction: monolithic approach and partitioned approach.11,12 For monolithic approach, it is hard to be achieved at the moment because of some obvious severe drawbacks like the complex modeling for both fluid and structure fields and large computational resources. For partitioned methods,13,14 the equations governing the flow and the displacement of the structure are separately solved in different solvers without any limitation. Furthermore, partitioned methods are divided into one-way and two-way coupling strategies. One-way coupling strategy is considered, for flow-induced vibration problems, only when the effect of fluid force is more significant than that of structure vibration on the flow. In addition, two-way coupling strategy is generally used for very strong non-linear coupled problems considering bidirectional effect simultaneously. Theoretically, two-way coupling strategy can obtain more accurate FSI results, but more time consuming; moving mesh and computation stability should be considered more.

In this article, the FSI simulations with one-way and two-way coupling strategies are carried out for the hydrodynamic force and vibration of single-blade pump impeller at design and off-design conditions with nominal rotating speed. And the comparisons between the results with two different strategies have been analyzed. Meanwhile, the effect of mesh resolution on the FSI results is also considered. In addition, the obtained FSI simulation results of impeller oscillation are compared with the experimental results. This article shows the effect of each strategy on the FSI simulation results of the pump, and offers an understanding of one-way and two-way coupling simulation strategies.

sec.title: Model pump
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows a picture of the investigated model pump, which is a commercial single-stage single-suction horizontal volute centrifugal pump with a single-blade impeller, of which the diameter of the pipes at the suction and pressure sides is 100 mm. The impeller outer diameter is 205 mm, and the blade width at the impeller outlet is 100 mm. Cross-sections of the flow channel with a minimum free ball passage of 100 mm can be realized. The casing of the pump is typical for sewage water pumps and combines an unbladed annulus with a volute. For measuring the radial deflection of the impeller, two non-contacting displacement measuring sensors are mounted on two vertical directions in stationary coordinate frame, shown also in Figure 1, and the deflection of outer side of the suction mouth of the impeller is considered for the test, while the numerical oscillation results are obtained from the exact same position. Furthermore, the design parameters of the pump are shown in Table 1, and the rotor structure is shown in Figure 2, including the single-blade impeller and the pump shaft. The material characteristic parameters of the rotor structure are also listed in Table 1. Figure 1.
A view of the test pump. Figure 2.
Rotor structure. Table 1.
Parameters of the pump.
Design parameters Material characteristic parameters
Delivery head Hdes 8 m Density ρ 7850 kg/m3
Flow rate Qdes 33.3 L/s Elastic modulus E 200 GPa
Rotation speed ndes 1440 r/min Poisson ratio μ 0.3

sec.title: FSI simulation setup
sec.p: In this contribution, the partitioned approach, including one-way and two-way load transfer coupling strategies for the FSI solution procedure, is selected because the fluid and structure domains are separated by an apparent boundary which is called fluid structure interface, and ANSYS Multi-field solver system 12.1 including Mechanical and CFX solvers is used.15

In Figure 3, the scheme of partitioned FSI simulation system is depicted in which the dashed line represents the one-way coupling procedure, while the solid line shows the procedure with two-way coupling strategy. For two-way coupling, the computation of flow field is first carried out using finite volume method, and some flow parameters are solved. Therefore, the hydrodynamic force on the fluid wetted surface can be obtained. Through the fluid–structure interface, the force load is transferred to the structural dynamic solver as the boundary conditions for the FEM analysis, and the deformation of the structure can be solved. And then, the convergence of the FSI calculation begins to be checked considering all individual load components transferred between two solvers. If the load transferred has converged at the specific convergence target, the FSI calculation will restart from the fluid field simulation for the next time step, otherwise, the FSI iteration will continue for the same time step. Furthermore, for one-way coupling procedure, no FSI convergence has been checked, and no multiple FSI iterations and no computation of modified mesh are considered, compared with two-way coupling. Figure 3.
Flow chart of coupled solution.

For fluid calculation part, three-dimensional, unsteady Reynolds-averaged Navier–Stokes equations are solved using the shear stress transport (SST) turbulence model. The structured grids for computational domains are generated using the grid generation tool ICEM-CFD 12.1, the grids in rotating domain are partially shown in Figure 4, and the number of grid nodes is totally 2,182,132 for both rotating and stationary domains. The maximum of non-dimensional wall distance y+ < 80 has been obtained for rotor mesh. Meanwhile, a coarse structured mesh, including 185,262 grid nodes, is also created using the same blocks for all domains in order to find out the influence of mesh resolution on the FSI results. The impeller side chambers are also included in the grid to take leakage flow effect into account. The discretization in space is of second-order accuracy, and the second-order backward Euler scheme is chosen for the time discretization. The interface between the impeller and the casing is set to ‘transient rotor-stator’ to capture the transient rotor–stator interaction in the flow, because the relative position between the impeller and the casing is changed for each time step with this kind of interface. And smooth wall condition is used for wall function. The chosen time step for the transient simulation is 3.47225 × 10−4 s for nominal rotating speed, corresponding to the changed angle of Δϕ = 3°. Within each time step, the iteration stops when maximum residual is less than 10−3, and the convergence criterion for the transient problem is that the result has reached its stable periodicity. Figure 4.
Computational fluid grid (fine mesh).

For structure FEM calculation part, the fluid–structure interfaces for all wetted surfaces of blade, shroud and hub, shown in Figure 2, are defined, respectively, including side chamber-wetted surfaces of shroud and hub. Furthermore, the face-fixed support boundary conditions are also indicated in Figure 2; therefore, the bearings amounting here are treated as rigid structure. Some other transient structural computation information are listed in Table 2. HHT method is employed for time integration of the transient dynamic equilibrium equation, which is an improved algorithm of the Newmark time integration method. In addition, Rayleigh damping is used in the solving system for input the damping effect to the transient analysis. Table 2.
Boundary conditions.
FSI solver ANSYS Multi-field solver with MFX simulation
Inlet Constant total pressure and flow direction
Outlet Constant mass flow rate
Walls Smooth and no-slip
Working fluid Water at 25°C, ρ = 998.2 kg/m3
Turbulence model SST
Discretization in space and time Second order
Convergence criterion Maximum residual <10−3 for fluid, residual <10−2 for load transfer and all results are periodic
Time integration method HHT
Beta damping value 0.1%
Numerical damping 0.4
Under relaxation factor 0.75

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
For analyzing the FSI results, two coordinate systems are defined, stationary coordinate frame marked as x, y and rotating coordinate marked as ψ,ξ, as shown in Figure 5. The rotation position of the impeller is indicated by defining the angle ϕ between positive ψ axis of rotating coordinate frame and positive y axis of stationary coordinate frame, and ϕ = 0° is obtained when the trailing edge of the impeller is at the top position. In addition, for obtaining the periodic stable rotor deflection results, six revolutions of coupling calculation were finished, and the obvious periodically stable results are achieved; therefore, the calculation results of one impeller revolution for analyzing later is obtained from the sixth calculated revolution. Figure 5.
Coordinate system definition.

sec.title: Computation time
sec.p:
All simulations were carried out on a PC with 4 CPU cores, and each core has the speed of 3.2 GHz. The HP MPI Local Parallel mode is used to achieve the efficient parallel FSI calculation. For the two-way coupling using fine mesh, the maximum computational time is approximately 35 h for one revolution, and for the two-way coupling using coarse mesh, the maximum computational time is about 15 h for one revolution. Figure 6 shows the comparison of the computational time for two-way coupling using different meshes. The much more time is required for the fine mesh because the number of calculation nodes is larger. And the calculation time with fine mesh is twice the time for the calculation with coarse mesh for the design condition, which is the smallest difference compared with other conditions. Figure 7 shows the time comparison of two different coupling strategies with same fluid mesh. The computational time with two-way coupling method is larger because each time step contains certain stagger iterations for achieving the load transfer convergence. The difference for the design condition is the biggest, and the time with two-way coupling is approximately four times longer than that with one-way coupling. Figure 6.
Computation time of different meshes. Figure 7.
Computation time of different coupling strategies.

sec.title: Influence of grid resolution
sec.p:
The two-way coupling results are compared for both fine and coarse meshes, and the measurement results are also shown for each operational condition, in Figure 8. All the conditions for FSI calculation, including CFD boundary conditions, boundary conditions for FEM analysis of structure, specified FSI simulation system and FSI calculation strategy, and others are the same except the CFD grid resolution in order to show the only influence of the fluid grid resolution on the FSI results. The arrows show the deflection vectors at an impeller rotation position of ϕ = 0° for both numerical and measurement results, and the initial position rotates in counterclockwise direction with increasing the flow rate. The deflection results at initial impeller positions of all the examined operational points are in the second quadrant, and the vectors rotate in the clockwise direction with the impeller rotation. Figure 8.
Impeller deflection results for different fluid meshes: (a) Q = 42 L/s, (b) Q = 33 L/s, (c) Q = 22 L/s, and (d) Q = 11 L/s.

For over-load condition Q = 42 L/s, shown in Figure 8(a), the amplitude of impeller deflection with fine mesh is bigger than that with coarse mesh in all the quadrants, while the phase predictions are almost the same and have quite good agreement with the measurement phase results. In addition, some deflections between FSI results and measurement results can be observed for about half of an impeller revolution, mainly in the second quadrant, and the deflection becomes smaller when fine mesh is used for calculation. For the design condition Q = 33 L/s, shown in Figure 8(b), the amplitude of deflection with fine mesh is still obviously bigger than the results with coarse mesh. And the calculated phases are nearly the same, but have a little phase lead compared with the experimental results. Figure 8(c) and (d) shows the comparison of FSI simulation results with two fluid mesh resolutions under part-load conditions. For Q = 22 L/s, the amplitude results with fine mesh are still bigger, especially in the second quadrant. The amplitude deviation between numerical and experimental results in the second quadrant is smaller when fine mesh is used. For Q = 11 L/s condition, the amplitude results for two mesh resolutions are nearly the same in the first quadrant, and the results with fine mesh are bigger in the other quadrants. In addition, the phase differences of FSI results with two mesh resolutions can be clearly found for part-load conditions, and the phase lead of numerical results can also be observed compared with measured results.

The time-dependent hydrodynamic force is the direct reason for oscillations of the single-blade pump impeller. Therefore, the radial forces in the absolute coordinate system for all the flow rates are computed using two-way coupling strategy, and for different mesh resolutions, the results are compared in Figure 9. The forces are regarded as the function of impeller rotation angle ϕ, and the arrows show the force vectors at an impeller rotation position of ϕ = 0°. To determine the amplitude of the radial force, the forces are divided by a reference force according to the following equation (1)Fref=ρ2u22b2r2 Figure 9.
Hydrodynamic force results for different fluid meshes: (a) Q = 42 L/s, (b) Q = 33 L/s, (c) Q = 22 L/s, and (d) Q = 11 L/s.
And dimensionless forces are obtained for both fine and coarse mesh results.

In addition, some non-physical oscillations with small amplitude of the force curves can be clearly found for each operational condition except Q = 22 L/s. Compared with the force results obtained by only CFD calculation in the study of Benra,4 those non-physical oscillations should be caused by the two-way coupling strategy, and the staggered load transfer iteration can affect the stability of the FSI calculation system. The stability of the FSI-partitioned method is, therefore, important for obtaining reasonable results. Furthermore, compared with the deflection results of the impeller structure in the same calculation system, the hydrodynamic force results is more sensitive to the stability of the partitioned FSI calculation strategy. But the non-physical oscillations of the force curves obtained here are still in the acceptable range. The initial value of force is also located in the second quadrant, and has the same regulation as the deflection results discussed above.

For Q = 42 L/s condition, shown in Figure 9(a), the amplitude of force calculated using coarse mesh is smaller than that is calculated with fine mesh, and the obvious difference of phases can be observed. Also the position of the non-physical oscillation is different for two result curves. For the design condition Q = 33 L/s, the amplitude of radial force for coarse mesh is also smaller, and two phases have a good agreement. For Q = 22 L/s condition, the clear difference between the force amplitudes of fine mesh and coarse mesh for the entire revolution can be seen, and the good agreement of the phases can also be observed. For the lowest examined flow rate Q = 11 L/s, the force amplitude results with fine mesh are smaller in the first quadrant and are bigger in other quadrants. And the phases have little difference.

sec.title: Comparison of one-way and two-way coupling results
sec.p:
The calculated results, both impeller deflection and hydrodynamic radial force, by one-way and two-way coupling strategies are compared for all examined flow rates in order to find out the influence of different coupling strategies on FSI results, shown in Figures 10 and 11. Except the coupling strategy, all the other parameters and conditions for FSI calculation including fluid mesh resolution are the same to eliminate the other effects on the results as much as possible. The measurement results for impeller oscillations are also shown. In Figure 10(a), the deflection results by two strategies for Q = 42 L/s are shown. The amplitude of deflection calculated by two-way coupling is bigger than that is calculated by one-way coupling method in the third quadrant, fourth quadrant, and parts of the second quadrant, and a good agreement can be observed in the first quadrant and rest part of the second quadrant. The phases of numerical results have a small lag compared with measured results, and little phase difference can be found between one-way and two-way coupling results. For design condition Q = 33 L/s, shown in Figure 10(b), the difference of calculated amplitudes by two strategies has the same regulation as for over-load condition. The calculated phase results are almost the same, and have a good agreement with measured results. For part-load conditions, shown in Figure 10(c) and (d), the difference of amplitude results obtained by one-way and two-way coupling can be observed in the first and second quadrants, where the two-way coupling result is still bigger, and the more obvious difference can be observed for Q = 11 L/s. In addition, a good agreement of amplitudes by two strategies can be seen in the third and fourth quadrants. Furthermore, the phase results obtained by two strategies are the same, but have phase leads compared with measured results. Figure 10.
Impeller deflection results for different coupling strategies: (a) Q = 42 L/s, (b) Q = 33 L/s, (c) Q = 22 L/s, and (d) Q = 11 L/s. Figure 11.
Hydrodynamic force results for different coupling strategies: (a) Q = 42 L/s, (b) Q = 33 L/s, (c) Q = 22 L/s, and (d) Q = 11 L/s.

Figure 11 shows the comparison of hydrodynamic force results calculated by one-way and two-way coupling strategies. Not quite obvious difference of force amplitude between one-way and two-way coupling results can be observed, and the amplitude calculated by one-way coupling method is just slightly smaller. And the phase difference can only be observed for Q = 42 L/s and Q = 11 L/s conditions. Compared with two-way coupling results, the phase lead is obtained for one-way coupling results under over-load condition, and the phase lag is observed under Q = 11 L/s condition. In addition, because the force results of one-way coupling procedure are not affected by the deformation of the impeller structure, more stable hydrodynamic force curves are obtained compared with the two-way coupling results.

Figure 12 shows the comparison of total impeller deformation results in FSI calculation procedure for Q = 33 L/s condition when ϕ = 0°. The obvious difference can be observed not only at the suction mouth where the strongest deflections appear, but also at rest part of shroud, blade and hub. The black area on the shroud, which represents the relatively large deformation at suction mouth, is larger when two-way coupling strategy is used, and the area representing relative large deformation on the hub is also bigger for two-way coupling results, compared with one-way coupling. Figure 12.
Comparison of total impeller deflection (Q = 33 L/s, ϕ = 0°).

The dynamic stresses in structures are computed based on the fourth strength theory. The von Mises or equivalent stress, σeq can be computed using (2)σeq=12[(σx-σy)2+(σy-σz)2+(σz-σx)2 +6(τxy2+τyz2+τxz2)]

Figure 13 shows the von Mises stress distributions on the rotor for Q = 33 L/s condition when ϕ = 0°. The maximum stress amplitude on the impeller can be observed at blade trailing edge, and the slight difference of the distributions can be seen here for different coupling strategies. In addition, the maximum amplitude of the stress distributions of the entire model is on the shaft near the position where the bearing is mounted, and the maximum value is 45.802 MPa obtained by two-way coupling. The difference of stress distributions on the shaft for one-way and two-way couplings can be also observed, and the color areas of each amplitude interval for different coupling strategies are slightly different. Figure 13.
Comparison of von Mises stress distributions (Q = 33 L/s, ϕ = 0°).

sec.title: Analysis of difference between FSI and measured results
sec.p:
Some possible reasons for the deviation of numerical and experimental deflection orbits have been discussed in detail in the literature,4 and except that some added possible causes should be noticed and improved further.
The dynamic characteristic (deformation) of the bearings during the pump running was not considered. Because the bearing was looked up as a rigid body, and the fixed support was used during the FSI investigation.
The complex flow behavior during the pump running in the seal was not taken into account. Furthermore, the flow in the seal was also totally different for the ‘wet’ and ‘dry’ operations for obtaining the hydrodynamic rotor deflection.
The vibration behaviors of the casing are different for ‘wet’ and ‘dry’ conditions, and that would affect the position of the proximity sensor relative to the rotor, because the sensors were mounted on the casing.
The alignment error of shaft coupling was not considered during the FSI calculation.
The convergence criterion used was 0.01 for load transfer process of FSI-partitioned calculation, which is the default value. The stricter criterion may be used to obtain more precise FSI result.
The deviation of casing shape from an ideal volute spiral during design and manufacture process may cause the difference between FSI and experimental results.
The imperfect CFD results for asymmetrical flow in the rotating impeller may affect the FSI results and cause the difference.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
In this article, one-way and two-way coupling strategies are used, respectively, for the FSI simulations. Not only the hydrodynamic force, but also the vibration of single-blade pump impeller at design and off-design conditions is carried out. Meanwhile, the effect of mesh resolution on two-way coupling results is also considered. The comparison analysis of the results shows the following conclusions.
The calculation time using fine mesh has the smallest difference with the calculation time using coarse mesh under design condition, and the biggest difference of computational time by two coupling strategies appears also under design condition.
The amplitude of deflection with fine mesh is bigger than that with coarse mesh for almost all the operational conditions, and the phase predictions for two mesh resolutions are almost the same under design and over-load conditions, while the phase differences can be clearly found for part-load conditions.
The amplitude of force calculated with coarse mesh is smaller than that is calculated with fine mesh in almost all quadrants for each condition except the first quadrant under Q = 11 L/s condition. The obvious phase difference can only be observed for over-load condition.
For over-load and design conditions, the amplitude of deflection calculated by two-way coupling is bigger than that is calculated by one-way coupling method in the third quadrant, fourth quadrant, and parts of the second quadrant, and for part-load conditions, the difference can be observed in the first and second quadrants. The phase results have a good agreement for different coupling strategies.
The amplitude of hydrodynamic force calculated by one-way coupling method is just slightly smaller, and the phase difference can only be observed for Q = 42 L/s and Q = 11 L/s conditions. More stable hydrodynamic force curves are obtained by one-way coupling method.
The maximum stress amplitude on the impeller can be observed at blade trailing edge, and the maximum amplitude of the entire rotor is on the shaft near the position where the bearing is mounted. And the only slight difference of stress distributions has been obtained.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study is supported by National Outstanding Young Scientists Founds of China (grant no. 50825902).

ack.p: The authors want to thank Dr. -Ing Jianjun Feng, Dipl. -Ing Sebastian Schuster and M.Sc. Bo Wan for providing support on FSI simulation work.
